geninfo.para: The function of the International 3 + 1 battery system is to isolate the three engine cranking batteries from an auxiliary deep cycle battery when the engine is off. The auxiliary deep cycle battery supplies nearly all vehicle electrical loads except for engine cranking. The engine can be started even though the auxiliary battery has been discharged due to such loads as electric blanket use, refrigerators, TVs, lights inadvertently left on, etc.

svcproc.title: OPERATION
svcproc.para: When the engine is turned off, the isolated battery 7-volt magnetic switch opens, isolating the auxiliary battery from the cranking batteries. Any accessories connected directly to the auxiliary battery continue to operate. In addition, placing the key switch in the "ACC" or "RUN" position closes the accessory 12-volt magnetic switch* supplying auxiliary battery power to any key switch controlled accessories. When the engine is started, the alternator "R" terminal output of 7 volts closes the isolated battery 7-volt magnetic switch. This connects all 4 batteries in parallel. The alternator can now charge all 4 batteries as well as supply power to all vehicle loads. (See circuit diagram - standard system ( Figure 1).
*Most installations use a 12-volt magnetic switch, however, a few do not (see circuit diagram - alternate system ( Figure 2).

warning.para: To prevent severe injury to the eyes, face, limbs, and body, it is imperative that lighted tobacco, flames or sparks be kept away from the vent openings of the battery. The gas mixture in the battery cells, which escapes through the vents, could ignite and/or cause an explosion. This is particularly true when jumper cables are being used.
In addition, inhaling of hydrogen gas produced by the normal operation of the battery could result in partial or permanent damage to the respiratory system.
Whenever disconnecting battery terminals, always disconnect ground terminal first. When reconnecting, always connect ground terminal last.
Always wear eye protection when working around batteries.
Failure to observe these instructions could result in personal injury and/or damage to the vehicle.

entry.para: Low or decreasing power to accessories with engine operating (discharged auxiliary battery).
Isolated 7-volt magnetic switch not closing or closing intermittently, with engine operating.
Perform the following tests with the engine operating:

1. Check voltage at 7-volt magnetic switch coil terminal. The coil terminal of the isolated 7-volt magnetic switch is supplied by the alternator "R" terminal and should be 7.0 volts ± 2.0 volts when measured with a digital voltmeter set on the DC volts scale.

2. The case of the 7-volt magnetic switch must be properly grounded. Check and tighten all mounting bolts between switch and mounting plate, and between the mounting plate and other components to assure good grounds. A test light should illuminate when connected between either one of the 7-volt magnetic switch large terminals and the case of the switch.

3. To test main internal contacts of the 7-volt magnetic switch, turn on headlights. Connect a temporary jumper (minimum 10 gauge) across the large terminals of the 7-volt magnetic switch. If the headlights brighten or if the voltmeter reading inside the cab goes up, replace 7-volt magnetic switch.

4. To test 7-volt magnetic switch for intermittent operation, gently tap switch case while observing headlight brightness. Headlights which dim between taps indicates intermittent operation. Also test for intermittent operation by temporarily disconnecting the coil wire. Repeatedly touch and hold the coil wire to the coil terminal. Headlights should brighten each time contact is made.
No power to accessories with the engine operating.
Auxiliary battery discharged and isolated 7-volt magnetic switch not closing, with engine operating
Perform the four Troubleshooting Tests under the first condition listed (Low or decreasing power to accessories with engine operating (discharged auxiliary battery).
No power to accessories with the engine operating.
12-volt magnetic switch* not closing or closing intermittently. (*Most installations use a 12-volt magnetic switch, however, a few do not (see circuit diagram - alternate system.)
Perform the following tests with the engine off:

1. Check voltage at 12-volt magnetic switch coil terminal. The coil terminal of the 12-volt magnetic switch is supplied by the cranking batteries through the ignition switch. With the cranking batteries fully charged and the ignition switch in the "ACC" position, the voltage at the coil terminal should not be less than 12 volts. A definite click should be heard at the 12-volt magnetic switch when turning the ignition switch from the "OFF" to the "ACC" position.

2. The base of the 12-volt magnetic switch must be properly grounded. Check and tighten all mounting bolts between switch and mounting plate, and between the mounting plate and other components to assure good grounds. A test light should illuminate when connected between the battery side of the 12-volt magnetic switch (large terminal) and the base of the switch.

3. To test main internal contacts of the 12-volt magnetic switch, turn ignition switch to "ACC" position and turn on headlights. Connect a temporary jumper (minimum 10 gauge) across the large terminals. If headlights brighten or if the voltmeter reading inside the cab goes up, replace 12-volt magnetic switch.

4. To test 12-volt magnetic switch for intermittent operation, gently tap switch case while observing headlight brightness. Headlights which dim or go out between taps indicates intermittent operation. Also test for intermittent operation by temporarily disconnecting the coil wire. Repeatedly touch and hold the coil wire to the coil terminal. Headlights should turn on each time contact is made.

Cranking batteries go dead.
Isolated battery magnetic switch wired incorrectly.
Re-wire.
NOTE 1. The voltmeter in the instrument cluster is connected to the isolated battery.
NOTE 2. Do not torque the large terminals on the magnetic switches over 6 ft-lbs.

NOTE 3. When charging batteries in a vehicle, connect a jumper between the cranking and auxiliary battery positive terminals. If this is not done, only the cranking batteries or the auxiliary battery (which ever is connected to the charger) will receive the charge, not both.
